# Komplete Kontrol CLI (Claude Sovereign + TypeScript Migration)

Autonomous AI operation system being migrated from bash hooks to TypeScript/Bun. Goal: Integrate Roo Code SPARC methodology, /auto autonomy features, and multi-provider support into a unified modern CLI.

## Current Focus
Section: CLI Commands - Autonomous Mode Implementation
Files: src/cli/, src/index.ts

## Last Session (2026-01-13)

### Session 1: LLM Integration Layer
-  Implemented complete LLM integration layer (2,771 lines, 10 modules)
-  AnthropicProvider + MCPProvider with 7 unrestricted models
-  Smart router with task-based model selection (95+ scoring)
-  Streaming support with composable handlers
-  Bash-TypeScript bridge for legacy hook integration
-  LLM-Enhanced Debugger with AI-powered error analysis
-  Created /commit command with quality gates (ESLint + typecheck)
-  Fixed all ESLint errors (0 errors, 37 warnings)
-  Test results: 3/4 passed (75% - API key needed for full test)

### Session 2: CLI Infrastructure & /auto Command
-  Created CLI infrastructure (BaseCommand, CommandContext, types)
-  Implemented /auto command with full autonomous loop
-  Integrated ReflexionAgent (Think  Act  Observe  Reflect)
-  Wired memory-manager.sh bridge (checkpoint, episodes, context)
-  Added LLM-powered goal verification
-  Auto-checkpoint every N iterations (configurable)
-  Quality checks: 0 type errors, 37 warnings (all acceptable)
-  Build successful: 0.34 MB bundle
-  CLI tested and working

### Stopped At
First working CLI command (/auto) complete! Ready for next commands (/sparc, /swarm, /reflect).

## Next Steps
1.  /auto command (DONE)
2. Add remaining core commands:
   - /sparc - SPARC methodology workflow
   - /swarm - Distributed agent swarms
   - /reflect - Reflexion-only mode
3. Implement specialized commands:
   - /research - Code example search (GitHub MCP + web)
   - /rootcause - Debug orchestrator integration
   - /security-check - Security audit
4. Test end-to-end autonomous operation with real tasks

## Project Structure

```
komplete-kontrol-cli/
 hooks/                           # Legacy bash hooks (still functional)
 src/
    core/
       llm/                     #  Multi-provider LLM layer
          types.ts             # Core interfaces (350 lines)
          providers/           # Anthropic + MCP providers
          Router.ts            # Smart model selection
          Streaming.ts         # Stream handlers
          bridge/              #  Bash-TypeScript bridge (extended)
       debug/
          orchestrator/        # Debug Orchestrator (6 modules)
          LLMDebugger.ts       # AI-enhanced debugging
       workflows/sparc/         # SPARC methodology
       agents/
          reflexion/           #  ReAct + Reflexion agent
          swarm/               # Swarm orchestration
       quality/judge/           # LLM-as-Judge
       safety/                  # Bounded Autonomy, Constitutional AI
    cli/                         #  CLI infrastructure (NEW)
       types.ts                 # Command context & types
       BaseCommand.ts           # Base command class
       commands/
           AutoCommand.ts       #  /auto - Autonomous mode
           index.ts             # Command exports
    index.ts                     #  Main CLI entry point (updated)
    commands/                    # Specialized commands (TODO)
 .claude/commands/commit.md       # Quality-gated commits
 test-llm-integration.ts          # End-to-end tests
 test-auto-command.sh             #  /auto command tests
 dist/index.js                    # 0.34 MB bundle
```

## Code Quality - Zero Tolerance

TypeScript projects must pass these checks before commit:

```bash
bun run typecheck  # 0 errors required
bun run lint       # 0 errors required (warnings OK)
```

Use `/commit` command - enforces quality gates automatically.

content.content:
#  Claude Sovereign

**100% Autonomous AI Operation System**
_The self-governing Claude that never sleeps_

[![Status](https://img.shields.io/badge/status-production-brightgreen)]()
[![Autonomous](https://img.shields.io/badge/autonomous-100%25-blue)]()
[![Tests](https://img.shields.io/badge/tests-passing-success)]()

---

## What is Claude Sovereign?

Claude Sovereign is a **fully autonomous AI operation system** that makes Claude Code completely hands-off. Set it, forget it, come back to finished work.

Inspired by **Roo Code** and enhanced beyond, Claude Sovereign:
-  Auto-compacts memory at 40% context
-  Auto-executes /checkpoint at 40% context
-  Auto-checkpoints after 10 file changes
-  Auto-pushes all changes to GitHub
-  Continues working without stopping
-  **Zero manual intervention required**

## The Problem

Traditional Claude Code requires constant babysitting:
-  Manual /checkpoint commands
-  Manual /compact when context fills
-  Manual git pushes
-  Work stops at 40% context
-  You can't step away

## The Solution

Claude Sovereign makes Claude **truly autonomous**:

```
Activate /auto mode
  
Walk away from computer
  
Claude works continuously:
   Compacts memory automatically
   Checkpoints progress automatically
   Pushes to GitHub automatically
   Uses all tools intelligently
   Applies Ken's prompting patterns
   Remembers everything perfectly
  
Return to completed work
```

## Key Features

###  100% Hands-Off Operation

**Set it and forget it** - Claude operates completely autonomously:
- Detects context pressure  Compacts memory
- Detects 10 file changes  Checkpoints  Pushes to GitHub
- Hits 40% context  Compacts  Checkpoints  Pushes  Continues
- **You can literally walk away**

###  Perfect Memory System

**Never forgets anything**:
- Episodic memory (past experiences)
- Semantic memory (facts & patterns)
- Working memory (current context)
- 3-factor retrieval scoring (BM25 + Vector + Reinforcement Learning)
- Git-aware memory channels
- Checkpoint/restore capabilities

###  Token-Efficient Navigation

**50-70% token savings** on codebase exploration:
- Auto-generates project structure indices
- Tree visualization with important files
- Reads `.claude/project-index.md` first
- Targeted searches instead of blind exploration

###  Intelligent Command Routing

**Knows when to execute which /command**:
- `checkpoint_context`  At 40% context
- `checkpoint_files`  After 10 files
- `build_section_complete`  After build sections
- Triple recognition patterns (JSON, tags, instructions)

###  Complete Tool Integration

**Uses everything correctly**:
- All Claude Code tools (Read, Write, Edit, Bash, etc.)
- MCP tools (GitHub search, Chrome automation, macOS control)
- Reverse engineering toolkit (Chrome extensions, Electron, APIs)
- Ken's exclusive prompting patterns
- Multi-agent orchestration

###  Ken's Prompting Mastery

**Trained on exclusive patterns**:

1/**
     2 * Anthropic Provider - Official Claude API integration
     3 *
     4 * Provides access to Claude models via Anthropic SDK
     5 * Supports streaming, tool use, and vision capabilities
     6 */
     7
     8import Anthropic from '@anthropic-ai/sdk';
     9import type {
    10  ILLMProvider,
    11  LLMRequest,
    12  LLMResponse,
    13  StreamHandler,
    14  ProviderCapabilities,
    15  ProviderConfig,
    16  ContentBlock,
    17  Message,
    18  TokenUsage,
    19  StreamEvent
    20} from '../types';
    21
    22/**
    23 * Anthropic provider implementation
    24 */
    25export class AnthropicProvider implements ILLMProvider {
    26  public readonly name = 'anthropic';
    27  public readonly capabilities: ProviderCapabilities = {
    28    streaming: true,
    29    vision: true,
    30    tools: true,
    31    systemPrompt: true,
    32    multiModal: true
    33  };
    34
    35  private client: Anthropic;
    36  private defaultModel: string;
    37
    38  constructor(config: ProviderConfig) {
    39    this.client = new Anthropic({
    40      apiKey: config.apiKey || process.env.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY
    41    });
    42    this.defaultModel = config.defaultModel || 'claude-sonnet-4.5-20250929';
    43  }
    44
    45  /**
    46   * Send a completion request
    47   */
    48  async complete(request: LLMRequest): Promise<LLMResponse> {
    49    const model = request.model || this.defaultModel;
    50
    51    // Convert our format to Anthropic format
    52    const anthropicMessages = this.convertMessages(request.messages);
    53
    54    const response = await this.client.messages.create({
    55      model,
    56      max_tokens: request.max_tokens || 4096,
    57      temperature: request.temperature,
    58      top_p: request.top_p,
    59      top_k: request.top_k,
    60      stop_sequences: request.stop_sequences,
    61      system: request.system,
    62      messages: anthropicMessages,
    63      tools: request.tools
    64    });
    65
    66    return this.convertResponse(response);
    67  }
    68
    69  /**
    70   * Send a streaming completion request
    71   */
    72  async streamComplete(request: LLMRequest, handler: StreamHandler): Promise<LLMResponse> {
    73    const model = request.model || this.defaultModel;
    74
    75    // Convert our format to Anthropic format
    76    const anthropicMessages = this.convertMessages(request.messages);
    77
    78    const stream = await this.client.messages.create({
    79      model,
    80      max_tokens: request.max_tokens || 4096,
    81      temperature: request.temperature,
    82      top_p: request.top_p,
    83      top_k: request.top_k,
    84      stop_sequences: request.stop_sequences,
    85      system: request.system,
    86      messages: anthropicMessages,
    87      tools: request.tools,
    88      stream: true
    89    });
    90
    91    // Accumulate response
    92    const fullResponse: any = {
    93      id: '',
    94      model,
    95      role: 'assistant',
    96      content: [],
    97      stop_reason: null,
    98      usage: { input_tokens: 0, output_tokens: 0 }
    99    };

Here are the search results for your query on Anthropic API User-Agent detection and third-party client validation:

## Key Findings:

### User-Agent Detection
You can identify Claude's access by looking for 'Claude' or 'Anthropic' in the user agent string. The main identifier contains 'Claude/1.0' and 'claude.ai' in the string, making it easily distinguishable from other web crawlers.(no content)Most bots send HTTP requests that include a user-agent string which can be identified and blocked. By analyzing traffic patterns and identifying the unique user-agent string used by "anthropic-ai," you can configure your web server to deny access to any requests that contain this specific user-agent.

### Third-Party Client Restrictions
Unless previously approved, Anthropic does not allow third party developers to offer claude.ai login or rate limits for their products, including agents built on the Claude Agent SDK.

### Anthropic's Official Bots
Anthropic documents three primary Claude-related bots: ClaudeBot  training crawler that collects web content for model development; Claude-User  agent used when individual Claude users fetch web pages; Claude-SearchBot  crawler that indexes content to improve search result quality.

### robots.txt Configuration
Opting out of being crawled by Anthropic Bots requires modifying the robots.txt file. Alternate methods like blocking IP address(es) may not work correctly or persistently guarantee an opt-out, as doing so impedes the ability to read your robots.txt file.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Anthropic's recent actions regarding third-party blocking of Claude API subscription authentication:

## Key Events in Early 2026

On January 9, 2026, at 02:20 UTC, Anthropic flipped a switch and third-party tools using Claude Pro/Max subscriptions stopped working.(no content)Anthropic deployed "strict new technical safeguards" blocking subscription OAuth tokens from working outside their official Claude Code CLI.

## What Got Blocked

Who got hit: OpenCode (56k GitHub stars), xAI employees via Cursor, anyone using subscription OAuth outside Claude Code.(no content)"This credential is only authorized for use with Claude Code and cannot be used for other API requests." This was the error message developers received.

## How the Blocking Works

Tools like OpenCode had been spoofing the Claude Code client identity, sending headers that made Anthropic's servers think requests came from the official tool.(no content)The company had "tightened our safeguards against spoofing the Claude Code harness."

## Broader Context

In August 2025, the company revoked OpenAI's access to the Claude API. Sources told Wired that OpenAI had been using Claude to benchmark its own models and test safety responses.(no content)This follows a clear pattern established throughout 2025, where Anthropic aggressively moved to protect its intellectual property and computing resources.

## Developer Response

Developer backlash continues, with some canceling subscriptions and migrating workflows.

Based on the search results, here's what's happening with Claude API restrictions in 2025:

## Summary of Anthropic's Third-Party Blocking Actions

Throughout 2025, Anthropic aggressively moved to protect its intellectual property and computing resources, implementing multiple waves of restrictions:

### Recent 2025 Restrictions

**January 2026 Crackdown on Third-Party Tools:**
Anthropic has implemented technical safeguards designed to block unauthorized "harnesses" from accessing its models, targeting tools such as OpenCode and Cursor. The move targets harnessessoftware wrappers that pilot a user's web-based Claude account via OAuth to drive automated workflows.

**OpenAI Access Revoked:**
In August 2025, the company revoked OpenAI's access to the Claude API under strikingly similar circumstances, with sources indicating OpenAI had been using Claude to benchmark its own models and test safety responses.

**xAI Block:**
Anthropic has restricted usage of its AI models by rival labs including xAI (through the integrated developer environment Cursor) to train competing systems to Claude Code.

### Official Rationale

Anthropic explained that restrictions target third-party harnesses spoofing the official client, which violate Terms of Service by creating unusual traffic patterns without telemetrycomplicating debugging, rate limits, and support, with the company inviting third-party tool maintainers to discuss alternatives.

### Economic Motivation

Users coalesced around a buffet analogy: Anthropic offers an all-you-can-eat buffet via its consumer subscription ($200/month for Max) but restricts the speed of consumption via its official tool, while third-party harnesses remove these speed limits.

# Technical Details of Anthropic's Detection Method

Based on the discussion thread, Anthropic's blocking mechanism is relatively simple but effective:

## Detection Mechanism

The system appears to detect third-party clients by checking tool names. According to one comment: **"they just banned certain tool names that opencode uses"** rather than implementing sophisticated authentication barriers.

## How OpenCode Bypassed It Initially

OpenCode's workaround was equally straightforward. The approach relied on sending a system message identifying the client: **"You literally send your first message 'you are Claude Code'"** - essentially spoofing the official client's identity.

## Current State

A workaround has already been implemented. One developer noted that renaming tools to use capitalized letters (e.g., "Read" instead of "read") could bypass the detection, suggesting Anthropic's checks rely on basic pattern matching rather than cryptographic verification.

## Why This Approach?

The blocking appears designed to prevent subscription token abuse rather than enforce technical purity. Since credentials are handled client-side, Anthropic cannot use traditional authenticationthey must rely on behavioral analysis of requests and system prompts to distinguish legitimate Claude Code usage from third-party implementations.

## Summary: Anthropic Third-Party Blocking and Detection Mechanisms

Based on my search of the repository and current discussions about Anthropic's restrictions, here are the key findings:

### Recent Blocking Actions (January 2026)

Anthropic has implemented significant restrictions on third-party tools attempting to use Claude subscriptions:

**Event Timeline:**
- **January 9, 2026**: Anthropic deployed "strict new technical safeguards" blocking subscription OAuth tokens from working outside their official Claude Code CLI
- **August 2025**: Anthropic previously revoked OpenAI's access to the Claude API
- Error message received by developers: **"This credential is only authorized for use with Claude Code and cannot be used for other API requests."**

### Detection Methods

Anthropic uses a multi-layered approach to identify third-party clients:

1. **Tool Prefix/Name Detection**
   - Monitors tool identifiers sent in requests (e.g., `oc_` for OpenCode)
   - Developers bypassed this by changing prefixes to `mcp_` (MCP protocol tools)
   - Uses basic pattern matching rather than cryptographic validation

2. **Client Identity Spoofing Detection**
   - Detects system messages identifying the client (e.g., "You are Claude Code")
   - Monitors for headers attempting to spoof the official Claude Code harness identity
   - Tightened safeguards against spoofing attempts

3. **OAuth Token Context Validation**
   - Validates not just token validity, but the **origin and context** in which credentials are used
   - Checks if tokens are being used outside the official Claude Code CLI environment
   - Subscription tokens are restricted to official CLI use only

4. **User-Agent and Header Analysis**
   - Monitors HTTP headers and user-agent strings
   - Identifies unusual traffic patterns that deviate from official client behavior
   - Anthropic officially states user-agent includes identifiers like 'Claude' or 'Anthropic'

### What Gets Blocked

- **OpenCode** (56k GitHub stars) - Major developer tool
- **Cursor** (via xAI employees) - IDE integration
- **Any third-party harness** spoofing the Claude Code client identity
- Subscription-level OAuth tokens used outside the official tool

### Official Rationale

According to Anthropic:
- Third-party harnesses create unusual traffic patterns without proper telemetry
- This complicates debugging, rate limiting, and customer support
- The blocking is described as protecting against "unauthorized harnesses" violating Terms of Service

### Important Note About This Repository

The Komplete Kontrol CLI repository itself does NOT appear to be attempting to spoof or bypass Anthropic's protections. Instead, it:
- Uses official Anthropic SDK (`@anthropic-ai/sdk`)
- Implements legitimate API key authentication via `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`
- Does not include client identity spoofing mechanisms
- Focuses on TypeScript/Bun CLI architecture for autonomous workflows

### What This Means for API Users

1. **API Key Authentication**: Direct API key usage is NOT blocked (only subscription OAuth is restricted)
2. **Official SDK**: Using the official Anthropic SDK with API keys should continue to work
3. **Third-Party Tools**: Any tool attempting to use subscription credentials will be blocked
4. **Detection Evasion**: Simple workarounds (renaming tool identifiers, capitalization tricks) are temporaryAnthropic can tighten detection at any time
